item.title: Thoughts on a scriptable hack (MW3)
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[code]public interface Kernel32 extends StdCallLibrary {
Kernel32 k32 = (Kernel32) Native.loadLibrary(“kernel32”, Kernel32.class);

    public Pointer OpenProcess(int dwDesiredAccess, boolean bInheritHandle, int dwProcessId);

    boolean ReadProcessMemory(Pointer hProcess, int inBaseAddress, Pointer outputBuffer, int nSize,
            IntByReference outNumberOfBytesRead);

}[/code]

is this what you need?

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on a scriptable hack (MW3)
item.dc:creator: @n3ss3s n3ss3s
item.description:
@n3ss3s wrote:

I have no experience with PB but I’m guessing they have usermode hooks for ReadProcessMemory/WriteProcessMemory, so one approach you might want to implement right away is make a function prototype for GetProcAddress (check MSDN), walk the EAT to get the address of GetProcAddress and cast that to your prototype, then use your new GetProcAddress to get the addresses to whatever functions you need.

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on a scriptable hack (MW3)
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

Punk Buster doesn’t have to find the actual hack itself. What most anti-cheats look for are common modifications used by hacks: external module injections, detours, useful WinAPI calls (ReadProcessMemory/WriteProcessMemory…). There are more advanced techniques that are starting to become detected as well, although not very reliably (I’m looking at you, VAC3).

If you want some more information, I advise you take a look at Game Deception’s anti-cheat sections.

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on a scriptable hack (MW3)
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:12, topic:424863”]He sent me a copy with source and I can confirm it does work. Also has a working BF3 hack using the same technique.

It makes sense to program this in Java as PB doesn’t scan the JVM, and if it did start to look at the loaded classes the code could be obfuscated.[/quote]

PB doesn’t have to scan the JVM. If the only reasons for using Java are: 1) PB not scanning the JVM, 2) Java bytecode being obfuscatable, then it’s dumb. You can encrypt a native executable, you can run it through a machine code obfuscator. Best approach would be to just hide the hack from PB using rootkit techniques. The detectability problem with hacks isn’t really the signatures, it’s the modifications that the hack makes to the game. PB now has silent bans, so retard T X’s hack is probably already detected, will just find out later. Right now he just uses WinAPI functions via JNA, according to his story Read/WriteProcessMemory to read/modify values. What if at one point you need to inject code to the game? Java is really the dumbest choice here.

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on a scriptable hack (MW3)
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

He sent me a copy with source and I can confirm it does work. Also has a working BF3 hack using the same technique.

It makes sense to program this in Java as PB doesn’t scan the JVM, and if it did start to look at the loaded classes the code could be obfuscated.

Read full topic

item.title: Thoughts on a scriptable hack (MW3)
item.dc:creator: @The_Enforcer The Enforcer
item.description:
@The_Enforcer wrote:

T X/Mark Gore is obviously an idiot. I just read this topic and asked him on MSN why he chose Java when he’s going to have to write most of the bot in native code. His only argument was: “PB doesn’t scan for bytecode signatures”. ROFL.

This doesn’t even seem to be a working example, just some usage of empty stub methods.

@Ollie wrote:

you made a spelling mistake in one of your scripts which leads me to believe this is only a concept and not currently a working solution.

AimBot

MWPlayer closest = [b]getPlayers()[/b].getNearest();

AutoKnife

MWPlayer closest = [b]getPlayer()[/b].getNearest();

item.title: Thoughts on a scriptable hack (MW3)
item.dc:creator: @b0nethugs b0nethugs
item.description:
@b0nethugs wrote:

What are your thoughts on a java scriptable MW3 hack…

Example

[code]import com.mw3.etewt3.models.wrappers.MWPlayer;
import com.mw3.etewt3.script.ScriptEngine;

/**

  • @author Mark Gore

*/
public class AimBot extends ScriptEngine {

@Override
public int loop() {
	MWPlayer closest = getPlayers().getNearest();
	if (closest != null) {

//true for shooting to. false for no shooting
closest.doAim(true);
return 100;
}
return 100;
}

@Override
public boolean toActivate() {
	MWPlayer closest = getPlayers().getNearest();
	if (closest != null && closest.distance > 3)
		return true;
	return false;
}

}[/code]

What are your thoughts on this?

[code]import com.mw3.etewt3.models.wrappers.MWPlayer;
import com.mw3.etewt3.script.ScriptEngine;
import com.mw3.etewt3.utils.Utils;

/**

  • @author Mark Gore

*/
public class AutoKnife extends ScriptEngine {

@Override
public int loop() {
	MWPlayer player = getPlayer().getNearest();
	if (player != null && player.getDistance() <= 3) {
		player.knife();
	}
	return 100;
}

@Override
public boolean toActivate() {
	return Utils.inMatch() && getPlayer().getNearest().getDistance() <= 3;
}

}[/code]

Read full topic
